doc.source_uri: 2025-09-02/Japan Technology_ IT Services_ NC company results read-across (1)_ IIJ (MVNO, networks), Dentsu Soken (SI_packaged software)_2025-09-02

passages.text: We highlight four points from the company's commentary. (1) Excluding the negative impact of VMware product price hikes, 1Q (Apr-Jun) operating profits rose by only \(+6\%\) yoy. While growth was limited on a real basis, earnings were generally in line with company expectations. (2) SI orders continued to grow by double digits (%), rising \(+13\%\) yoy, as the market for network infrastructure construction is expanding across the industry. The order environment remains more favorable than the company had expected. (3) Outsourcing service sales rose \(+14\%\) yoy/+1% qoq, marking slower qoq growth. However, the company said this was due to the timing of security project launches, and that the sales expansion trend remains unchanged. The negative impact of security incidents has been limited so far. (4) 2Q operating profit guidance calls for \(+9\%\) yoy growth on a real basis excluding one- off factors, implying a slight acceleration in growth from 1Q (excluding the impact of VMware).
However, 2H guidance calls for \(+15\%\) yoy growth, meaning the company will need to further accelerate growth on a real basis. See Exhibit 3 for IIJ's earnings. We discuss the details below.

1Q results: 1Q (Apr-Jun) operating profits rose sharply to ¥6.03 bn \((+35\%\) yoy, \(+¥1.55\) bn). However, excluding the negative impact of VMware product price hikes in 1Q last year (¥1.2 bn, including cost increases and provisions), profits rose by only \(+6\%\) yoy. By segment (gross profit basis), network services \((+9\% / + ¥0.97\) bn yoy; \(+6\%\) yoy excluding the impact of VMware) saw growth mainly in IP services, MVNO, and security, while SI \((+49\% / + ¥1.56\) bn yoy; \(+16\%\) yoy excluding the impact of VMware) saw margin improvement due to an increase in operation projects. Network services were impacted by an increase in facility- related costs for 5G SA (standalone) support (a - ¥0.3 bn yoy drag on profits). While growth was limited on a real basis, results were generally in line with company expectations.

SI business: SI order growth remained in double- digit percentages, rising \(13\%\) yoy, with strength in both construction/equipment sales \((+13\%\) yoy) and operation/maintenance (also \(+13\%\) ) (Exhibit 1). While the market for network infrastructure construction is expanding across the industry, IIJ is seeing growth above the overall market, mainly in the financial and public sectors, and the order environment remains more favorable than the company had expected. IIJ looks for continued order growth, albeit with quarterly volatility. Meanwhile, sales rose \(4\%\) yoy overall, with construction/equipment sales down \(- 7\%\) yoy and operation/maintenance up \(+11\%\) yoy. The decline in construction business sales was in line with the company's expectations, and IIJ said sales could bottom out given that the order environment is currently stronger than it had expected. The gross margin improved by \(+4.3\) pp yoy, or \(+1.4\) pp yoy excluding the impact of VMware. This was due to an increase in the weighting of high- margin operation/maintenance business, a trend the company expects to continue.
Exhibit 1: 1Q orders continued to grow by double digits (%; strong demand for network construction IIJ: SI business orders
Source: Company data, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research
Exhibit 2: QoQ sales growth slowed sharply, but this was quarterly variance; negative impact of security incidents limited IIJ: Outsourcing business sales
Source: Company data, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Network services business: Network service sales/gross profits rose \(+7\% / + 9\%\) yoy, or \(+6\%\) yoy excluding the impact of VMware. The gross margin declined on a real basis excluding the impact of VMware due to an increase in fixed costs such as

personnel expenses and 5G SA support costs. By service, the number of IP service contracts declined slightly on seasonal impact due to contract switching (consolidating lines reduces the number of contracts but increases ARPU), and the expansion trend is unchanged as growth in total bandwidth for internet connection service contracts is accelerating. Sales continue to grow at a high rate owing to factors such as price increases. MVNO contracts rose a steady \(+3\%\) qoq, driven by the launch of JAL's mobile service. The business continued to perform well excluding the impact of this as well, mainly on new rate plans. Outsourcing service sales rose \(+14\%\) yoy/+1% qoq, marking slower qoq growth (Exhibit 2). However, the company said this owed to the timing of security project launches (such as SASE), and that the uptrend in sales is unchanged given the level of inquiries. Negative fallout (such as customer cancellations) from security incidents has been limited so far.

- Outlook: FY3/26 guidance is unchanged. Implied 2Q operating profit guidance of ¥9.47 bn (+30%/+¥2.17 bn yoy) represents growth of +9% yoy on a real basis excluding one-off factors (the dropout of the -¥0.4 bn impact of VMware and gains on the reversal of provisions for retirement benefits of slightly over ¥1.0 bn). This implies a slight acceleration in growth from 1Q (excluding the impact of VMware). The company said that price increases will continue to contribute to network services, and that SI sales could recover (mainly in construction/equipment sales) as the order environment is stronger than expected. However, 2H guidance calls for +15% yoy growth, meaning the company will need to further accelerate growth on a real basis as VMware-related impact drops out.
Exhibit 3: IIJ (3774.T): Earnings by segment
Source: Company data, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Dentsu Soken (4812.T): Signs of recovery in financial and business solutionsWe highlight three key points from company commentary. (1) 1H12/25 operating profits only edged up, falling short of guidance due to sluggish demand in financial solutions and manufacturing solutions. However, 2Q (Apr-Jun) operating profits rose 6% yoy, a slight acceleration in growth driven by the business solutions segment (wider demand for proprietary software) and Dentsu- related business. (2) 2Q orders were lackluster, rising by only 1% yoy. This owed largely to the absence of large- scale projects in manufacturing solutions and SAP- related business. Inquiries are recovering on a real basis, mainly in financial solutions and business solutions. The financial solutions business is expanding, mainly among banks, while large- scale projects are starting to move in business solutions for mainstay systems such as STRAVIS (consolidated accounting), POSITIVE (human resource management), and \(\mathrm{Ci}^* \mathrm{X}\) (expense management). (3) FY12/25 operating profit guidance (¥23.0 bn, \(+9\%\) yoy) is unchanged. 2H guidance calls for operating profits of ¥12.3 bn (+16% yoy), implying an acceleration in growth. The company expects momentum to pick up in financial solutions and business solutions, where orders are on a recovery trend, with growth also underpinned by the dropout of unprofitable projects (approximately ¥0.3 bn in manufacturing solutions) and stable growth in Dentsu- related business. See Exhibit 6 for Dentsu Soken's earnings. We discuss the details below.

1H and 2Q12/25 results: 1H operating profits came to ¥10.7 bn (+3% yoy), only edging up and falling short of guidance (¥11.5 bn). The main factor was weaker- than- expected demand for financial solutions and manufacturing solutions. The financial solutions unit was unable to offset the loss of two large- scale projects in FY12/24 with other projects, while the manufacturing solutions unit was unable to offset the dropout of a large- scale SAP project. Dentsu Soken said the impact of reciprocal tariffs on corporate investment was limited, and was not a factor in the shortfall. As discussed below, the company maintained its full- FY12/25 guidance despite the shortfall in 1H. 2Q (Apr- Jun) operating profits rose \(+6\%\) yoy to ¥4.88 bn (+¥0.28 bn yoy), a slight acceleration in growth. By segment, financial solutions (- 24%/- ¥0.25 bn yoy) struggled due to a high yoy hurdle and declining demand, mainly among banks and leasing companies, while manufacturing solutions (- 4%/- ¥60 mn yoy) saw profitability decline due to the absence of high- margin SAP projects. However, profit growth was driven by business solutions (+29%/+¥0.44 bn yoy), which began to benefit from large- scale projects for its mainstay HR management and consolidated accounting systems, and communication IT (+35%/+¥0.15 bn yoy; Exhibit 4) on a recovery in Dentsu- related business. Business solutions booked an impairment loss (¥0.31 bn) as some modules under development for an HR management system were deemed unnecessary, but the segment saw strong profit growth thanks to the favorable demand environment.
Exhibit 4: Sales to Dentsu bottoming out Dentsu-related business
Source: Company data, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Exhibit 5: 20 orders edged up, but excluding the impact of large-scale projects dropping out, orders are on a recovery trend, mainly in manufacturing solutions and communication IT Dentsu Soken: Orders by segment
Source: Company data, Data compiled by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research

Order climate: 2Q orders rose \(1\%\) yoy, but fell \(3\%\) yoy excluding the impact of new consolidation ( \(1.4 bn\) ). The lackluster growth was mainly due to the absence of large- scale projects in manufacturing solutions and communication IT (Exhibit 5). On a real basis, inquiries are on a recovery trend, mainly in financial solutions and business solutions. Financial solutions orders \((+8\%\) yoy) are picking up, fueled by growth in BANK R (loan/screening system) and customer management systems, mainly for banks. Business solutions orders \((+40\%\) yoy) have been in a lull between projects, but large- scale projects are starting to move for mainstay systems such as STRAVIS (consolidated accounting), POSITIVE (HR management), and Ci\\*X (expense management), and the company is winning new customers. Manufacturing solutions orders continued to decline \((- 17\%\) yoy) on the dropout of a large- scale SAP project. The company expects the impact of this to persist in 2H, but inquiries are strong for CAD/CAE/PLM software that contributes to productivity improvements. These products are a strategic area for manufacturers, and investment appetite remains strong despite reciprocal tariffs. Communication IT orders edged down \((- 3\% / - 0.3\) bn yoy), but this was largely due to the dropout of a collaborative project with Dentsu for the public sector (worth about \(3.0bn\) ). Inquiries for Dentsu- related business are on a recovery trend in real terms. While the Dentsu Group continues to struggle overseas, its domestic business is performing well, and development projects for peripheral systems associated with core systems are increasing.

Guidance: While FY12/25 sales guidance for financial solutions and manufacturing solutions was revised downward to reflect 1H progress, the company maintained FY12/25 operating profit guidance ( \(23.0bn, +9\%\) yoy), given unused SG&A budget and a lower personnel expense outlook owing to a reduction in hiring plans. Implied 2H operating profit guidance of \(12.3bn (+16\%\) yoy, \(+1.66bn\) yoy) therefore assumes an acceleration in growth. The company expects momentum to pick up in financial solutions and business solutions, where orders are on a recovery trend, with growth also underpinned by the dropout of unprofitable projects (approximately \(0.3bn\) in manufacturing solutions) and stable growth in Dentsu- related business.

The company said that while large- scale projects are concentrated in 4Q rather than 3Q this year, orders are on a recovery trend, and it expects the business environment to recover to some extent from 3Q. One- off factors include the dropout of unprofitable projects in manufacturing solutions (approximately \(+90.3\) bn), the cost of holding a 50th anniversary event (roughly \(- 0.1 - 0.2\) bn, already factored into guidance), and fluctuations in bonus provisions (approximately \(+90.3\) bn, as the company made higher provisions in 3Q12/24).
Exhibit 6:Dentsu Soken (4812.T): Earnings by segment

I, Chikai Tanaka, CFA, hereby certify that all of the views expressed in this report accurately reflect my personal views about the subject company or companies and its or their securities. I also certify that no part of my compensation was, is or will be, directly or indirectly, related to the specific recommendations or views expressed in this report.
Unless otherwise stated, the individuals listed on the cover page of this report are analysts in Goldman Sachs' Global Investment Research division.

The Goldman Sachs Factor Profile provides investment context for a stock by comparing key attributes to the market (i.e. our universe of rated stocks) and its sector peers. The four key attributes depicted are: Growth, Financial Returns, Multiple (e.g. valuation) and Integrated (a composite of Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple). Growth, Financial Returns and Multiple are calculated by using normalized ranks for specific metrics for each stock. The normalized ranks for the metrics are then averaged and converted into percentiles for the relevant attribute. The precise calculation of each metric may vary depending on the fiscal year, industry and region, but the standard approach is as follows:

Growth is based on a stock's forward- looking sales growth, EBITDA growth and EPS growth (for financial stocks, only EPS and sales growth), with a higher percentile indicating a higher growth company. Financial Returns is based on a stock's forward- looking ROE, ROCE and CROCI (for financial stocks, only ROE), with a higher percentile indicating a company with higher financial returns. Multiple is based on a stock's forward- looking P/E, P/B, price/dividend (P/D), EV/EBITDA, EV/FCF and EV/Debt Adjusted Cash Flow (DACF) (for financial stocks, only P/E, P/B and P/D), with a higher percentile indicating a stock trading at a higher multiple. The Integrated percentile is calculated as the average of the Growth percentile, Financial Returns percentile and (100% - Multiple percentile).

Financial Returns and Multiple use the Goldman Sachs analyst forecasts at the fiscal year- end at least three quarters in the future. Growth uses inputs for the fiscal year at least seven quarters in the future compared with the year at least three quarters in the future (on a per- share basis for all metrics).
For a more detailed description of how we calculate the GS Factor Profile, please contact your GS representative.

Across our global coverage, we examine stocks using an M&A framework, considering both qualitative factors and quantitative factors (which may vary across sectors and regions) to incorporate the potential that certain companies could be acquired. We then assign a M&A rank as a means of scoring companies under rated coverage from 1 to 3, with 1 representing high (30%- 50%) probability of the company becoming an acquisition target, 2 representing medium (15%- 30%) probability and 3 representing low (0%- 15%) probability. For companies ranked 1 or 2, in line with our standard departmental guidelines we incorporate an M&A component into our target price. M&A rank of 3 is considered immaterial and therefore does not factor into our price target, and may or may not be discussed in research.

Quantum is Goldman Sachs' proprietary database providing access to detailed financial statement histories, forecasts and ratios. It can be used for in- depth analysis of a single company, or to make comparisons between companies in different sectors and markets.

Buy (B), Neutral (N), Sell (S) Analysts recommend stocks as Buys or Sells for inclusion on various regional Investment Lists. Being assigned a Buy or Sell on an Investment List is determined by a stock's total return potential relative to its coverage universe. Any stock not assigned as a Buy or a Sell on

an Investment List with an active rating (i.e., a stock that is not Rating Suspended, Not Rated, Early- Stage Biotech, Coverage Suspended or Not Covered), is deemed Neutral. Each region manages Regional Conviction Lists, which are selected from Buy rated stocks on the respective region's Investment Lists and represent investment recommendations focused on the size of the total return potential and/or the likelihood of the realization of the return across their respective areas of coverage. The addition or removal of stocks from such Conviction Lists are managed by the Investment Review Committee or other designated committee in each respective region and do not represent a change in the analysts' investment rating for such stocks.

Total return potential represents the upside or downside differential between the current share price and the price target, including all paid or anticipated dividends, expected during the time horizon associated with the price target. Price targets are required for all covered stocks. The total return potential, price target and associated time horizon are stated in each report adding or reiterating an Investment List membership.
Coverage Universe: A list of all stocks in each coverage universe is available by primary analyst, stock and coverage universe at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html.

Not Rated (NR). The investment rating, target price and earnings estimates (where relevant) are removed pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when Goldman Sachs is acting in an advisory capacity in a merger or in a strategic transaction involving this company, when there are legal, regulatory or policy constraints due to Goldman Sachs' involvement in a transaction, and in certain other circumstances. Early- Stage Biotech (ES). An investment rating and a target price are not assigned pursuant to Goldman Sachs policy when this company neither has a drug, treatment or medical device that has passed a Phase II clinical trial nor a license to distribute a post- Phase II drug, treatment or medical device. Rating Suspended (RS). Goldman Sachs Research has suspended the investment rating and price target for this stock, because there is not a sufficient fundamental basis for determining an investment rating or target price. The previous investment rating and target price, if any, are no longer in effect for this stock and should not be relied upon. Coverage Suspended (CS). Goldman Sachs has suspended coverage of this company. Not Covered (NC). Goldman Sachs does not cover this company.

This research is for our clients only. Other than disclosures relating to Goldman Sachs, this research is based on current public information that we consider reliable, but we do not represent it as accurate or complete, and it should not be relied on as such. The information, opinions, estimates and forecasts contained herein are as of the date hereof and are subject to change without prior notification. We seek to update our research as appropriate, but various regulations may prevent us from doing so. Other than certain industry reports published on a periodic basis, the large majority of reports are published at irregular intervals as appropriate in the analyst's judgment.

Goldman Sachs conducts a global full- service, integrated investment banking, investment management, and brokerage business. We have investment banking and other business relationships with a substantial percentage of the companies covered by Global Investment Research. Goldman Sachs & Co. LLC, the United States broker dealer, is a member of SIPC (https://www.sipc.org).

Our salespeople, traders, and other professionals may provide oral or written market commentary or trading strategies to our clients and principal trading desks that reflect opinions that are contrary to the opinions expressed in this research. Our asset management area, principal trading desks and investing businesses may make investment decisions that are inconsistent with the recommendations or views expressed in this research.

The analysts named in this report may have from time to time discussed with our clients, including Goldman Sachs salespersons and traders, or may discuss in this report, trading strategies that reference catalysts or events that may have a near- term impact on the market price of the equity securities discussed in this report, which impact may be directionally counter to the analyst's published price target expectations for such stocks. Any such trading strategies are distinct from and do not affect the analyst's fundamental equity rating for such stocks, which rating reflects a stock's return potential relative to its coverage universe as described herein.

We and our affiliates, officers, directors, and employees will from time to time have long or short positions in, act as principal in, and buy or sell, the securities or derivatives, if any, referred to in this research, unless otherwise prohibited by regulation or Goldman Sachs policy.

The views attributed to third party presenters at Goldman Sachs arranged conferences, including individuals from other parts of Goldman Sachs, do not necessarily reflect those of Global Investment Research and are not an official view of Goldman Sachs.

Any third party referenced herein, including any salespeople, traders and other professionals or members of their household, may have positions in the products mentioned that are inconsistent with the views expressed by analysts named in this report.

This research is not an offer to sell or the solicitation of an offer to buy any security in any jurisdiction where such an offer or solicitation would be illegal. It does not constitute a personal recommendation or take into account the particular investment objectives, financial situations, or needs of individual clients. Clients should consider whether any advice or recommendation in this research is suitable for their particular circumstances and, if appropriate, seek professional advice, including tax advice. The price and value of investments referred to in this research and the income from them may fluctuate. Past performance is not a guide to future performance, future returns are not guaranteed, and a loss of original capital may occur. Fluctuations in exchange rates could have adverse effects on the value or price of, or income derived from, certain investments.

Certain transactions, including those involving futures, options, and other derivatives, give rise to substantial risk and are not suitable for all investors. Investors should review current options and futures disclosure documents which are available from Goldman Sachs sales representatives or at https://www.theocc.com/about/publications/character- risks.jsp and https://www.goldmansachs.com/disclosures/cftc_fcm_disclosures. Transaction costs may be significant in option strategies calling for multiple purchase and sales of options such as spreads. Supporting documentation will be supplied upon request.

Differing Levels of Service provided by Global Investment Research: The level and types of services provided to you by Goldman Sachs Global Investment Research may vary as compared to that provided to internal and other external clients of GS, depending on various factors including your individual preferences as to the frequency and manner of receiving communication, your risk profile and investment focus and perspective (e.g., marketwide, sector specific, long term, short term), the size and scope of your overall client relationship with GS, and legal and regulatory constraints. As an example, certain clients may request to receive notifications when research on specific securities is published, and certain clients may request that specific data underlying analysts' fundamental analysis available on our internal client websites be delivered to them electronically through data feeds or otherwise. No change to an analyst's fundamental research views (e.g., ratings, price targets, or material changes to earnings estimates for equity securities), will be communicated to any client prior to inclusion of such information in a research report broadly disseminated through electronic publication to our internal client websites or through other means, as necessary, to all clients who are entitled to receive such reports.

All research reports are disseminated and available to all clients simultaneously through electronic publication to our internal client websites. Not all research content is redistributed to our clients or available to third- party aggregators, nor is Goldman Sachs responsible for the redistribution of our research by third party aggregators. For research, models or other data related to one or more securities, markets or asset classes (including related services) that may be available to you, please contact your GS representative or go to https://research.gs.com.
Disclosure information is also available at https://www.gs.com/research/hedge.html or from Research Compliance, 200 West Street, New York, NY 10282.
